document.docAuthor: Ng, Peter K. L. & Rahayu, Dwi Listyo
document.masterDocTitle: A synopsis of Typhlocarcinops Rathbun, 1909 (Crustacea: Decapoda: Brachyura: Pilumnidae), with descriptions of nine new species from the Indo-West Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A synopsis of Typhlocarcinops Rathbun, 1909 (Crustacea: Decapoda: Brachyura: Pilumnidae), with descriptions of nine new species from the Indo-West Pacific

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of
Typhlocarcinops Rathbun, 1909

paragraph.keyLead: 1a. Anteroexternal angle of merus of third maxilliped projected to varying degrees, clearly auriculiform (e.g., Figs. 56A , 71A , 73A , 80B )............................................................................................... 2
1b. Anteroexternal angle of merus of third maxilliped rounded, not projected, not auriculiform (e.g., Figs. 60A , 69A )......... 7

2b. Merus of third maxilliped clearly shorter than ischium; dorsal margin of ambulatory merus unarmed; dactylus of ambulatory legs styliform, longer than or subequal to propodus; third maxilliped exopod and G1 otherwise........................ 3

3b. Carapace more than 1.2 times as broad as long, surface smooth, glabrous or with scattered granules and tubercles; fingers of chela not strongly gaping when closed..................................................................... 4

4a. Carapace and cheliped very smooth, appearing almost shiny, surfaces glabrous, without any tubercles ( Fig. 72B ); exopod of third maxilliped relatively broad; G1 with upper half slightly shorter than lower half, with 1 large seta subdistally ( Fig. 73 C‒F) ( Bohol , Philippines ; Tanimbar, Indonesia )..........................................
Typhlocarcinops lapillus
n. sp.

4b. Carapace and chelipeds covered with granules and/or tubercles partially or entirely; exopod of third maxilliped relatively slen- der; upper and lower halves of G1 subequal, row of fine setae subdistally......................................... 5

5a. Outer surface of palm with longitudinal rows of large tubercles on entire surface ( Fig. 67 E–G); G1 strongly curved, distal part slender, long, tapering to a relatively sharp tip ( Fig. 69C, D ) ( Singapore )...............
Typhlocarcinops diminutus
n. sp.
5b. Outer surface of palm otherwise; G1 slender, gently curved, distal part short...................................... 6

7a. Distinct lobes on anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small granules, separated by clear depressions, cleft between second and third anterolateral lobes very distinct, usually U-shaped............................................. 8

7b. Anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small granules or almost smooth, entire or if lobes visible, not clearly demarcated, cleft between second and third anterolateral lobes shallow or V-shaped.......................................... 11

9a. Outer surface of palm of cheliped smooth, ventral margin distinctly cristate ( Fig. 42D ); lower margin of ischium of third maxilliped strongly oblique ( Fig. 44A ); male pleon relatively narrow, telson 1.9 times as long as somite 6 ( Fig. 44B ); upper half of G1 shorter than lower half, distal part curved, flared, with rounded tip ( Fig. 44 C–F) ( Hong Kong , Vietnam ; Arafura Sea, Indonesia )...................................................................
Typhlocarcinops raouli
n. sp.

10b. Merus and ischium of third maxilliped subequal, exopod relatively slender ( Fig. 61B ); male pleon relatively broad, telson 1,7 times as long as somite 6 ( Fig. 61G ); G1 slender, sinuous, upper half distinctly longer, distal part directed upwards with pointed tip ( Fig. 61 H–L) ( Red Sea ).................................................
Typhlocarcinops serenei Türkay, 1986
11a. Anterolateral margin of carapace with cleft between second and third anterolateral lobes shallow or V-shaped........... 12
13a. Anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small tubercles, entire or separated into 4 broad lobes.................... 14
13b. Anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small tubercles, entire or separated into less than 4 lobes.................. 15

14a. Cheliped palm smooth medially, upper and lower surfaces with scattered tubercles ( Figs. 8F , 9G, H , 10E, F , 11F ); tooth on inner angle of carpus strong, pointed ( Figs. 10C, D , 11G, H ); exopod of third maxilliped slender, narrow ( Figs. 13B , 14A, F , 15B ); G1 with upper half distinctly longer than lower half, distal part short, gently curved ( Figs. 13 D–G, I–L, 14B–E, H–K, 15E–G) (Gulf of Thailand ; Phuket , Thailand ; Singapore ; Indonesia ; Hong Kong ).....
Typhlocarcinops canaliculatus Rathbun, 1909

14b. Cheliped palm smooth medially, upper, lower surface with dense setae especially on minor chela, setae may be absent in larger specimens ( Figs. 16F, G , 19E , 20E, F , 21E, F ); tooth on inner angle of carpus low, blunt ( Figs. 19F , 20C , 21D , 22G, H ); exopod of third maxilliped stout, relatively broad; G1 with upper and lower halves subequal in length, distal part long, prominently curved ( Figs. 18E , 23 B–E, H–K, 24A–G) ( Sulu , Philippines ; Papua , Indonesia ; Hong Kong ; Fujian , China )...............................................................................
Typhlocarcinops decrescens Rathbun, 1914

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 81 .
Heteropilumnus
sp., female (11.5 × 9.3 mm) (NHM), New Guinea. A, overall habitus; B, left maxilliped; C, D, dorsal view of carapace.

paragraph.keyLead:
15a. Anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small tubercles separated into 2 broad, low lobes ( Figs. 25B , 26B , 27B ); surface of cheliped palm smooth ( Figs. 25E , 26F , 27E ); tooth on inner angle of carpus strong, pointed ( Figs. 25F, G , 26B , 27F, G ); male pleon narrow ( Figs. 29B, G , 30B ); G1 with upper and lower halves subequal, distal part relatively long, gently bent, sinuous with pointed tip ( Figs. 28 , 29 C–F, H–J, 30C–F) (Kyushu, Japan ; Guangdong , China ; Hong Kong )..........................................................................
Typhlocarcinops denticarpes Dai, Yang, Song & Chen, 1986

15b. Anterolateral margin of carapace lined with small tubercles separated into 3 broad lobes ( Figs. 35A , 36A, B ); surface of cheliped palm smooth medially, upper and lower surface with scattered tubercles ( Fig. 35F, G ); tooth on inner angle of carpus long, sharp in large males ( Figs. 35E ) or angular and tuberculate in smaller specimens and females ( Fig. 36 C–E); male pleon broad ( Fig. 37B ); G1 with upper part half longer than lower half, distal part relatively short, gently bent, with pointed tip ( Fig. 37 C–F) ( Papua , Indonesia )............................................................
Typhlocarcinops robustus
n. sp.
16a. Carapace surface covered with relatively dense short and long setae............................................ 17
16b. Carapace surface with median surface glabrous, lateral margins covered with less dense short setae................... 18

17a. Carapace 1.4–1.5 times as broad as long ( Figs. 62A, B , 63B ); inner angle of carpus of cheliped with sharp denticulate protuberance ( Fig. 63A ); P2‒P5 relatively short ( Figs. 62A , 63B ); male pleon broad ( Fig. 64B ); G1 slightly curved, upper half longer than lower half, distal part slightly sinuous, tip broad, pointed upwards ( Fig. 64 C–F) (Lombok, Indonesia )............................................................................................
Typhlocarcinops hirtus
n. sp.

17b. Carapace 1.2 times as broad as long ( Fig. 34A ); inner angle of carpus of cheliped denticulate; P2‒P5 relatively long; male pleon narrow ( Fig. 34D ); G1 strongly sinuous, distal part gently curvedupwards, tip upcurved ( Fig. 34 E–G) ( Queensland , Australia ).........................................................
Typhlocarcinops tonsuratus Griffin & Campbell, 1969

18b. Outer surface of palm of cheliped entirely granular or smooth; inner angle of carpus with short, blunt dentition; P2‒P5 reltively short or long; male pleon narrow, telson less than 1.7 times as long as somite 6; G1 otherwise........................ 19

20a. Carapace surface smooth, anterolateral margin entire ( Fig. 50A, B ); exopod of third maxiliped slender ( Fig. 52A ); inner angle of carpus of cheliped low, with sharp granules ( Fig. 51A ); male telson 1.7 times as long as somite 6 ( Fig. 52B ); G1 slender, slightly curved in lower half, upper half sinuous, distal part with pointed tip ( Fig. 52 C–G) (South Java , Indonesia )...................................................................................
Typhlocarcinops hadrotes
n. sp.

20b. Carapace surface granular, anterolateral margin entire (or with broad lobes); exopod of third maxiliped stout; inner angle of carpus of cheliped with sharp spine or spinules; male telson 1.8–1.9 times as long as somite 6; G1 otherwise............ 21

21b. Outer surface of palm of chelipeds smooth ( Figs. 47G , 48D ); P2‒P5 relatively short ( Figs. 47A , 48A ); male pleon narrow, tel- son 1.9 times as long as somite 6 ( Fig. 49B ); G1 slender, curved, upper half longer than lower half, distal part directed obliquely upwards with pointed tip ( Fig. 49 C–F) ( Madagascar )..............................
Typhlocarcinops atimovatae
n. sp.
